author: SamMonoRT
body:
Several failures seen when running the JIT/Methodical/* tests. These are CoreCLR tests run on the mono runtime from the dotnet\runtime repo.

Repro :
Command to run individual tests :
```
cd src/mono/netcore
make run-tests-coreclr CoreClrTest="bash ../../artifacts/tests/coreclr/OSX.x64.Debug/JIT/Methodical/Arrays/huge/_il_relhuge_r8/_il_relhuge_r8.sh"
```


From comments below - Many of the tests were fixed via recent fixes. The only tests failing now are :

JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_do/dblarray2_cs_do.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_r/dblarray2_cs_r.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_ro/dblarray2_cs_ro.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray3_cs_do/dblarray3_cs_do.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_d/dblarray2_cs_d.sh

And the reason why they are failing is because mono hasn't implemented GC.EndNoGCRegion().




Failures :  (Some of them could have been fixed by recent fixes in last couple weeks).
1. JIT/Methodical/Arrays/huge/_il_relhuge_r8/_il_relhuge_r8.sh
2. JIT/Methodical/Arrays/huge/_il_relhuge_objref/_il_relhuge_objref.sh
3. JIT/Methodical/Arrays/misc/_il_relldelem_get/_il_relldelem_get.sh
4. JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_do/dblarray2_cs_do.sh  
5. JIT/Methodical/Arrays/huge/_il_relhuge_b/_il_relhuge_b.sh
6. JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_r/dblarray2_cs_r.sh
7. JIT/Methodical/VT/port/_il_dbghuge_gcref/_il_dbghuge_gcref.sh

9. JIT/Methodical/Invoke/25params/25paramMixed_il_d/25paramMixed_il_d.sh
10. JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_ro/dblarray2_cs_ro.sh

nodes.author: fanyang-mono
nodes.body:
The only failing tests now are

JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_do/dblarray2_cs_do.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_r/dblarray2_cs_r.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_ro/dblarray2_cs_ro.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray3_cs_do/dblarray3_cs_do.sh
JIT/Methodical/doublearray/dblarray2_cs_d/dblarray2_cs_d.sh

And the reason why they are failing is because mono hasn't implemented GC.EndNoGCRegion().

nodes.author: fanyang-mono
nodes.body: Assign this to Nathan, since the missing API is on the to-be-added GC API's on Nathan's list.

title: CoreCLR tests on Mono runtime : Failures in JIT/Methodical/* tests due to missing implementation of GC.EndNoGCRegion().

author: Maoni0
body:
please see the description of it in [the API proposal](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/34648#issuecomment-642362942). 

the PR for the coreclr implementation is [here](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/37879).

author: imhameed
body:
See [GCSettings.Mono.cs](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/15be6302e64b2a5df7d169bff7a2e876e1e4d400/src/mono/netcore/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/Runtime/GCSettings.Mono.cs).

Currently, [GC/API/GCSettings/InputValidation.cs](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/15be6302e64b2a5df7d169bff7a2e876e1e4d400/src/tests/GC/API/GCSettings/InputValidation.cs) and [GC/Features/LOHCompaction/lohpin.cs](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/15be6302e64b2a5df7d169bff7a2e876e1e4d400/src/tests/GC/Features/LOHCompaction/lohpin.cs) are disabled on Mono because our implementation of `SetGCLatencyMode` and `SetLOHCompactionMode` only support `GCLatencyMode.Batch` and `GCLargeObjectHeapCompactionMode.Default`.

title: [Mono][Android] Unhandled Exception: System.ArgumentOutOfRangeException: Index was out of range. Must be non-negative and less than the size of the collection. (Parameter 'index')

author: nealef
body:
There are differences between the CoreCLR and Mono JITs w.r.t. calculating physical memory sizes when running under cgroups.

There is a Red Hat test case that demonstrates the issue: 
https://github.com/redhat-developer/dotnet-regular-tests/tree/main/cgroup-limit

This simply calls the `GC.GetGCMemoryInfo().TotalAvailableMemoryBytes` routine.

In CoreCLR this routine is implemented via `GCToOSInterface::GetPhysicalMemoryLimit` which generally uses `sysconf(_SC_PHYS_PAGES)` to determine the physical memory size. However, it also has a separate call out to `GetRestrictedPhysicalMemoryLimit` in `src/coreclr/gc/unix/cgroup.cpp` which consults any limit that might have been set on the cgroup.

In Mono, on the other hand, the C# routine is implemented via `mono_determine_physical_ram_size` in `src/mono/mono/utils/memfuncs.c`, which always just uses `sysconf(_SC_PHYS_PAGES)` and does not check for cgroup memory limits.

This will cause the JIT to think that much more memory is available on the system than actually is allowed to be used by the process (when running in a restricted cgroup, e.g. in a container).

I am considering adapting the CoreCLR code to provide similar function to Mono. Mono has APIs for getting total memory and available memory whereas CoreCLR returns total and used. The simplified APIs would do the following:

* For TotalMemory –
  *    Get cgroup `memory.limit_in_bytes` (cgroupv1) or `memory.max` (cgroupv2) = [L]
  *    Check `getrlimit(RLIMIT_AS)` and use min() of [L] and soft limit [S] = [G]
  *    Get min() of [G] and `sysconf(_SC_PHYS_PAGES)` [P] = [M]
  *    Return [M]
* For AvailableMemory –
  *    Determine [M] – total_rss from `[cgroup_path]/memory.stat` [R] = [A]
  *    Return [A]

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
It would be nice to factor this out to https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/tree/main/src/native/common so that we have just one copy of this logic. It has been changing a lot.

Similar problem exists for processor limits (e.g. value returned by `Environment.ProcessorCount`). I do not think Mono respects the cgroup for that either.

nodes.author: SamMonoRT
nodes.body: @BrzVlad - moving this to 8.0.0, but something to consider sooner rather than later.

title: Mono does not consider cgroup constraints when determining memory sizes

author: BrzVlad
body:
The handling of OOM in mono is pretty buggy and it needs work.

- [ ] there are a lot of places within the GC where we don't handle allocation failure. While we throw OOM when we fail to allocate an object, we don't handle allocation failures during a GC. Instead we assert / crash. We should attempt to do error checking for out of memory, at least during GC, which is a common scenario for OOM crashes.
- [ ] `max-heap-size` does not guarantee that the heap will not get larger before throwing OOM
- [x] pinning of objects for which we failed to allocate copy does not work with concurrent GC
- [ ] most of the time, once we reach OOM scenario, we fail to throw exception because allocation of exception object fails

Issue Details
In mono, there are a lot of places where we don't handle allocation failure. While we throw OOM when we fail to allocate an object, we don't handle allocation failures during a GC. Instead we assert / crash. We should attempt to do error checking for out of memory, at least during GC, which is a common scenario for OOM crashes.

title: [mono] Improve handling of OOM

author: jahnotto
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When allocating large arrays in Blazor wasm 6.0.1, the memory is never freed up when the reference is set to null. Consecutive allocations ends up with an OutOfMemoryException.

Either I'm doing something very wrong, or there is a memory leak.

### Expected Behavior

The GC should free the memory that is no longer used, and should not result in an OutOfMemoryException.

### Steps To Reproduce

Minimal repro project is here: https://github.com/jahnotto/BlazorWasmMemoryIssue

Try to click multiple times on "Allocate DotNet memory". The memory keeps increasing. Clicking "Free DotNet memory" does not make any difference. Same behavior is seen in debug, release and even AOT.

Allocating JS memory, on the other hand, works as expected.

### Exceptions (if any)

OutOfMemoryException

### .NET Version

6.0.101

### Anything else?

Blazor wasm 6.0.1
Tested on both Edge and Chrome

Note: GCSettings.GCLatencyMode is set to Batch in Blazor wasm and can't be changed. I don't know if this relevant, but I'd expect it to be Interactive for an interactive client side application.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13984876/150339066-1a18fe87-7794-426c-af1d-b59c0dc46061.png)

I don't know if this relevant, but I'd expect it to be Interactive for an interactive client side application. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13984876/150339066-1a18fe87-7794-426c-af1d-b59c0dc46061.png)

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
I'm not convinced this is a leak, simply because the array size is very large relative to the maximum memory size. The GC is not really deterministic: objects can sometimes remain pinned and not get collected, the GC can therefore increase the trigger limit for next collection and the memory usage can spiral out of control.

@jahnotto Could you please test the behavior with a smaller array size like 128MB ? If you do iterations of Alloc/Free would you ever encounter unbounded memory growth ?

nodes.author: Fabi
nodes.body: It's an issue in server and client side blazor. Even trying to force collecting memory won't work. it's all referenced somewhere in native memory behind the scenes. This is expected behavior according to all these MS guys but it should NOT happen. For months users are just getting blamed to wait for the GC to collect memory because stuff gets freed very late or never at some point or when you run out of memory. This should get fixed ASAP!

nodes.author: jahnotto
nodes.body:
Thanks for following up @BrzVlad . I have done some more testing.

1.  Allocating 128 MB instead of 512 MB seems to work better. The memory keeps increasing, but only up to a certain point. I'm not getting an exception anymore.
2. I have added a WPF test project in the repro project which is doing exactly the same thing (with 512 MB allocations). Here you can see that the GC is behaving very differently than in Blazor:
- Memory is increasing until a certain point, but does not result in an exception
- If I call GC.Collect(), the memory is freed. This seems to have no effect in Blazor
- GCSettings.LatencyMode is Interactive, as opposed to Batch in Blazor.

Edit @BrzVlad Not sure what you mean by "iterations of alloc/free"? I'm clicking allocate and free multiple times. With big arrays, memory consumption grows and end up with exception on Blazor, but not in WPF. Both are .NET 6.

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body:
In the sample `_memoryUsed` is populated by calling [`window.performance.memory.usedJSHeapSize`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Performance/memory) in JS

I'm not sure if we shrink the .NET heap after we do a Mono GC and return that memory to JS.  Assuming we don't, I wouldn't expect to see the JS heap size decrease after a mono collection.  /cc @lewing

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: @jahnotto On WASM the available memory is much lower, and 512MB is a significant portion of it. I don't think it is a fair comparison. So if any such huge object gets pinned the memory can quickly increase. I'm assuming this is the reason why it works with 128MB. It's unclear to me if the used memory is excessive or not. Also WPF and WASM use completely different GCs with different heuristics and capabilities. It would be useful to see some logs of the application with `MONO_LOG_LEVEL=debug` and `MONO_LOG_MASK=gc` enabled. @lewing Do we still have a way to enable this log ?

nodes.author: jahnotto
nodes.body: I see your point. Is there anything I can do somehow to free the memory?

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: It sounds like you are running into limitations of the current wasm memory model, see the discussion here https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/issues/1397

nodes.author: Mindorf
nodes.body: Agree, this seems to be an open issue. We are observing something like this as well.

nodes.author: MikeReedGH
nodes.body:
Hi,

Is there any update on this issue?

We are running a .Net 7 Blazor Wasm app and having this exact issue. It is crippling our production deployment.
We either get an out of memory exception or the browser just force restarts the application.

Does anybody have a workaround or fix for this?

Thank you

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
I think this issue is not actionable, not sure why it is open. The original submitted sample has allocation patterns that are not really relevant for real world applications. I think this issue might as well be closed.

Applications can run out of memory from various reason, including excessive memory consumption at the application level, especially given wasm has less available memory. Also mono gc can have somewhat increased memory consumption because we are conservatively keeping alive more objects than we could in theory, when we scan roots from stack for example. If you think your application is not allocating excessive memory or leaks memory and it's the GC's fault that it fails to collect it, then I would encourage you to submit a new issue with a sample reproduction app. Otherwise this is not currently actionable.

nodes.author: jahnotto
nodes.body: Our application is very much a real-world application, although the original submitted sample was simplified to isolate the problem. Allocating arrays of more than 200 MB (100 MB in some cases) causes the GC to never collect it, even when there are no references to it. It is causing major issues for us.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
It is expected for a ref to an object to linger around a little bit more on the stack after the object becomes logically dead, keeping the object still allocated. It is unclear to me if you are experiencing a few objects just living a bit longer, or if they are incorrectly pinned throughout the application leading to OOM. I can't tell or investigate without a proper sample application.

Also you could prevent this by reusing large arrays, which is the recommended approach anyway since large objects are allocated directly to the major generation, their allocation is expensive and problematic when the memory becomes fragmented.

nodes.author: MikeReedGH
nodes.body:
@BrzVlad . Thanks for replying. 

The problem comes as soon a user selects a photo/or takes a camera photo, then the WASM app just immediately crashes and restarts. It's not a silly bug in my handling of the IBrowserFile. I have quadrupled checked.
It happens seemingly randomly, it will work fine for hours and then suddenly just crash.
It just smells like a memory leak, and I really thought I had found it when reading about this bug.
I am running out of ideas :(

Thanks

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: I would need some form of repro. Even if it is not always crashing, but exhibiting some high memory spikes that shouldn't happen.

nodes.author: jahnotto
nodes.body:
> It is expected for a ref to an object to linger around a little bit more on the stack after the object becomes logically dead, keeping the object still allocated. It is unclear to me if you are experiencing a few objects just living a bit longer, or if they are incorrectly pinned throughout the application leading to OOM. I can't tell or investigate without a proper sample application.
> 
> Also you could prevent this by reusing large arrays, which is the recommended approach anyway since large objects are allocated directly to the major generation, their allocation is expensive and problematic when the memory becomes fragmented.

Yep, that's the nature of the gc! However, any array larger than 100 MB is completely ignored by the gc forever. It seems like the data is never recollected, even after using the application for an hour. Eventually it will crash with an OutOfMemoryException.

We have tried reusing the arrays using a pool. However, the the number and size of the arrays will vary, and eventually new arrays that are bigger than arrays that are already in the pool will be required.

Even worse, even memory allocated by the framework itself is never reclaimed in many cases. This happens e.g. when in HttpClient's buffer when downloading large files (100+ MB).

I'll be happy to provide a repo, but I'm unsure exactly what you need. The original repo that I provided reproduces the exact problem.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: Overall these issues seem to be caused by the runtime conservatively scanning the entire stack and pinning all objects that have refs lingering on the stack, even if the objects might have been logically dead. Historically mono GC has always been conservative with scanning roots from regs/stack. On wasm-AOT it is particularly difficult to implement due to arch limitations and it is unlikely to happen any time soon. In the interpreted mode it is doable and a first step in this direction was done for .net 9 https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/100400

author: tannergooding
body:
.NET has two concepts regarding how types are allocated and laid out in memory. The first is `alignment` and ensures that the address for a new allocation is always evenly divisible by the target alignment. The second is `packing` and ensures that the offset for a field relative to the containing type is always evenly divisible by the target packing.

These concepts are similar and having correct alignment should also guarantee correct packing. They are currently treated differently due to GC limitations, however. For example, `Vector128<T>` has `16-byte` packing and is supposed to also have `16-byte` alignment. The `packing` is always respected, regardless of whether the data is on the stack or heap and this means that for a `struct S { byte x; Vector128<byte> y; }` the `y` field is at offset `16`. The `alignment` however, due to existing GC limitations, is not respected and the data encountered may be 4 or 8-byte aligned instead (there is a best effort, but not a guarantee that stack locals will be correctly aligned).

Mono does not currently respect the `packing` or the `alignment` for various ABI primitives (that is types that are considered "primitive" to the underlying Application Binary Interface for a given platform and therefore have well defined semantics).

The non runtime primitive types that need to be specially handled are at least:
* `Vector64<T>`
* `Vector128<T>`
* `Vector256<T>`
* `Int128`
* `UInt128`

It would also be worthwhile to validate that `CLong`, `CULong`, and `NFloat` are properly handled as well.

The first is `alignment` and ensures that the address for a new allocation is always evenly divisible by the target alignment. The second is `packing` and ensures that the offset for a field relative to the containing type is always evenly divisible by the target packing. These concepts are similar and having correct alignment should also guarantee correct packing. They are currently treated differently due to GC limitations, however. For example, `Vector128` has `16-byte` packing and is supposed to also have `16-byte` alignment. The `packing` is always respected, regardless of whether the data is on the stack or heap and this means that for a `struct S { byte x; Vector128 y; }` the `y` field is at offset `16`. The `alignment` however, due to existing GC limitations, is not respected and the data encountered may be 4 or 8-byte aligned instead (there is a best effort, but not a guarantee that stack locals will be correctly aligned). Mono does not currently respect the `packing` or the `alignment` for various ABI primitives (that is types that are considered "primitive" to the underlying Application Binary Interface for a given platform and therefore have well defined semantics). The non runtime primitive types that need to be specially handled are at least: * `Vector64` * `Vector128` * `Vector256` * `Int128` * `UInt128` It would also be worthwhile to validate that `CLong`, `CULong`, and `NFloat` are properly handled as well.

author: naricc
body:
Collecting issues here related to missing GC APIs in mono

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/35960
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/37950
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/42883

# Required for net 8.0:
- `AddMemoryPressure` Calls into runtime, but does not do anything: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-mono.c#L2872



# Not Required for net 8.0, but for full coreclr parity 
Right now these GC APIs throw `NotSupportedException`:

- `GCSettings.LatencyMode` (allows only LatencyMode.Batch,  Aggressive throws not supported; implementable in Mono?)
- `GC.TryStartNoGCRegion()`  (throws not supported) 
- `GC.RegisterForFullGCNotification()`  (throws not supported) 
- `GetTotalPauseDuration()` (throws not supported) 
- `GetConfigurationVariables` (it's ok if this returns different keys/values for mono)


This was implemented but the test is still disabled because were issues to be investigated, seehttps://github.com/mono/mono/issues/15236. There are also more fields to be implemented: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.gcmemoryinfo?source=recommendations&view=net-7.0
- `GC.GetGCMemoryInfo`

nodes.author: vargaz
nodes.body: It could be, on mono, its very hard to guarantee that a finalizer runs.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body: Yeah I never managed to write a reliable test for it on the wasm binding side so I gave up.

nodes.author: AntonLapounov
nodes.body:
> on mono, its very hard to guarantee that a finalizer runs.

Note that `P.count == 0` and `Q.count == 0` means none of 200 finalizers was executed.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
If I understand this situation right: It's wasm so there's no finalizer thread[1] so you would need to do a complex dance on the main thread at some point before exit where you do GCs repeatedly to fill the finalizer queue, then run all the finalizers on the queue. I'm sure we make a best effort to do something like this already but I'm not certain it would be possible to make it reliable. Wasm also scans the stack conservatively so any stray garbage on the stack could be keeping objects alive and preventing finalization.

[1] since threads are off by default right now

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body:
Could `GC.WaitForPendingFinalizers` just pump the finalizer queue synchronously on wasm? or is that just inviting deadlock?

As written, I agree this can't guarantee finalization on wasm

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/c7eb44d11bb5acca6ccc40de42314663cbaff145/src/tests/baseservices/critical_finalization/critical_finalization.cs#L38-L51

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body:
@lambdageek where did we land on this?

cc @pavelsavara

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body:
@lewing wishlist or wont fix, I think.

`GC.WaitForPendingFinalizers` cannot do the right thing on single-threaded wasm since there is no finalizer thread. I suggested pumping the queue synchronously, that's maybe worth trying, but I'm not sure it will do the right thing in general

title: [wasm] `critical_finalization` runtime test fails on Linux

author: BrzVlad
body:
On mono, this method expects arguments as if it operates on full array elements, however, behind the scenes, it ends up multiplying element count with element size, operating without relying on alignment of array elements.

Remove this constraint so we can use implementation from https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/78450 also on mono.

Issue Details
On mono, this method expects arguments as if it operates on full array elements, however, behind the scenes, it ends up multiplying element count with element size, operating without relying on alignment of array elements. Remove this constraint so we can use implementation from https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/78450 also on mono.

Issue Details
I wanted to see what happens when a Wasm process is configured for memory64. It didn't do anything, but it did demonstrate that some values are wrong. Code: ```csharp using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; Console.WriteLine($"Hello {RuntimeInformation.OSDescription}:{RuntimeInformation.OSArchitecture}"); Console.WriteLine($"Memory available: {GC.GetGCMemoryInfo().TotalAvailableMemoryBytes}"); Console.WriteLine($"With love from {RuntimeInformation.FrameworkDescription}"); ``` Result: ``` Hello WASI:Wasm Memory available: -16187392 With love from .NET 8.0.0 ``` `TotalAvailableMemoryBytes` should not be negative. This was the same, `memory64` or otherwise.

author: akravch
body:
### Android application type

.NET Android (net7.0-android, net8.0-android, etc.)

### Affected platform version

.NET 8.0.101, Android workload 34.0.52, Android NDK 26.1.10909125

### Description

Here is one of the top crashes that we are getting from production users:

```
SIGSEGV /SEGV_MAPERR

libmonosgen-2.0.so mono_gc_wbarrier_generic_store_internal
libmonosgen-2.0.so mono_gc_wbarrier_generic_store_internal
libmonosgen-2.0.so mono_gc_wbarrier_generic_store_internal
libc.so            0xf0358e24 + 986660
```

Seeing this crash for different Android versions from 6 to 14.

We were able to collect a few partial ADB logs, so I'm attaching them to the issue ([logs.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/14085729/logs.zip)). In every log I can see a line like that:

```
TrafficStats: tagSocket(260) with statsTag=0xffffffff, statsUid=-1
```

Also sometimes there are connection related exceptions:

```
Exception caught while cancelling connection: Java.IO.IOException: Canceled
   at Java.Interop.JniEnvironment.InstanceMethods.CallVoidMethod(JniObjectReference instance, JniMethodInfo method, JniArgumentValue* args)
   at Java.Interop.JniPeerMembers.JniInstanceMethods.InvokeAbstractVoidMethod(String encodedMember, IJavaPeerable self, JniArgumentValue* parameters)
   at Java.Net.HttpURLConnectionInvoker.Connect()
   at Xamarin.Android.Net.AndroidMessageHandler.<>c__DisplayClass133_0.<ConnectAsync>b__0()
  --- End of managed Java.IO.IOException stack trace ---
java.io.IOException: Canceled
	at com.android.okhttp.internal.http.StreamAllocation.findConnection(StreamAllocation.java:183)
	at com.android.okhttp.internal.http.StreamAllocation.findHealthyConnection(StreamAllocation.java:128)
	at com.android.okhttp.internal.http.StreamAllocation.newStream(StreamAllocation.java:97)

	at com.android.okhttp.internal.huc.HttpURLConnectionImpl.connect(HttpURLConnectionImpl.java:131)

So it looks like network may be related somehow, although it can as well just be a coincidence since our app uses network pretty much always.

No repro, only crash reports from production.

_No response_

nodes.author: filipnavara
nodes.body:
I have just been debugging a similar issue. There was a nearly identical stack trace with `mono_debugger_agent_unhandled_exception` as the one above. It turned out that the whole stack trace is incorrect and not symbolicated with the debug symbols. You can download the symbols using the `dotnet-symbol` tool and hopefully apply them in your crash reporting tool to get a correct stack trace.

It's likely that it will reveal an assert that is actually failing. In the case I investigated it was this one:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/04538da4fc4dca4a5f1184708fe95a16dd947d17/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-tarjan-bridge.c#L1144

That means at least one of the crashes is https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/106410 and there are some workarounds suggested on that issue.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: The stacktraces above are not correct so there is not any information to go from. If you are indeed impacted by random GC related crashes you could try the workarounds from the issue linked by Filip and you could also try disabling concurrent GC: `<AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>false</AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>`, to see if it has any effect.

nodes.author: PureWeen
nodes.body: @jonathanpeppers thoughts?

nodes.author: pijnappel
nodes.body: Any suggestions on how to track this down? I have no idea where to start looking.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
If you can reproduce the crash with extra logging on.
```
adb shell setprop debug.mono.log default,assembly,mono_log_level=debug,mono_log_mask=all
```
That might give more information.

As the message mentions the Mono GC (`SGen worker`), we can move this to dotnet/runtime for the right folks to look at this.

nodes.author: pijnappel
nodes.body:
I was able to reproduce the crash with extended Mono logging.
Here is the full logcat:

[SIGABRT.log](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/files/14773891/SIGABRT.log)

nodes.author: am11
nodes.body: Stacktrace looks similar to the one in https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/96804. Its fix is in latest <kbd>[8.0.3](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/releases/tag/v8.0.3)</kbd> runtime release (not sure how it corresponds to 8.0.7 SR2 series in the top comment). cc @lambdageek

nodes.author: lambdageek
jonathanpeppers
nodes.body: @pijnappel do you know what version of the runtime you are using? 8.0.2? We could probably use `dotnet-symbols` and `ndk-stack` to get line numbers.

nodes.author: pijnappel
nodes.body:
I'm not really sure. I'm usually up to date and install all updates. How do I get the runtime version used by my app?
I cannot reproduce the error when compiled in Debug. Is there any doc I can follow to get symbols and ndk-stack?

nodes.author: am11
nodes.body: Something like `dotnet tool install --global dotnet-symbol`, then download symbols for all installed libs: `sudo dotnet symbol --recurse-subdirectories --timeout 20 --symbols '/usr/share/dotnet/*.so'`, then download for your app: `dotnet symbol--timeout 20 --symbols path/to/your-app-binary` (which may or may not fail depending on the form factor). Finally, run the app under debugger (like lldb or gdb).

nodes.author: pijnappel
nodes.body:
We found a workaround. The crashes vanish if we deactivate concurrent garbage collection in the project settings.

`<AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>False</AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>`

I am not sure about the side effects and impacts on performance. When running calculation processes, we see random pauses of the execution for 300ms or more. I assume this happens when the GC is triggered. I haven't found a way to pause the GC for the duration of our calculations.

title: Random app crashes - SIGABRT in SGen Worker

author: verdie-g
body:
### Description

OutOfMemoryExceptions are thrown after allocating more than ~1 GB in a Blazor Wasm app.

This is a duplicate of https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/55694 that got closed but the issue is not solved.

### Reproduction Steps

1. `dotnet new blazorwasm -n BlazorTest`
2. Add this method to Home.razor
```csharp
protected override void OnInitialized()
{
    const int bufferSize = 64 * 1000;
    const int oneGig = 1_000_000_000;
    List<byte[]> list = [];
    for (int i = 0; i < oneGig / bufferSize; i += 1)
    {
        list.Add(new byte[bufferSize]);
    }
}
```
3. `dotnet run --project BlazorTest`
4. Observe OOM in the console

### Expected behavior

Because wasm uses a 32-bits addressing, I would expect to be able to use 4 GB of memory.

### Actual behavior

OOM is thrown after allocating ~1 GB of memory.
```
System.OutOfMemoryException: Out of memory
   at BlazorTest.Pages.Home.OnInitialized() in /home/gverdier/repos/BlazorTest/Pages/Home.razor:line 17
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.ComponentBase.RunInitAndSetParametersAsync()
```

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Configuration

.NET: 8.0.100
OS: Ubuntu x64
Browser: Google Chrome 125

### Other information

_No response_

nodes.body: Did you try setting EmccMaximumHeapSize to something larger?

nodes.author: verdie-g
nodes.body:
I've just tried setting
```
<EmccMaximumHeapSize>4294967296</EmccMaximumHeapSize>
```
in my csproj but it still OOMs.

nodes.body: can you try setting EmccInitialHeapSize to something large as well?

nodes.body:
Same behavior with
```
<EmccInitialHeapSize>3000000000</EmccInitialHeapSize>
<EmccMaximumHeapSize>4294967296</EmccMaximumHeapSize>
```

author: dcrespo-isaac
body:
### Android framework version

net8.0-android

### Affected platform version

.NET 8.0.100, .NET 8.0.303

### Description

Our Android application started to crash randomly 3 months ago when we upgraded it to .net6. 
We tried to add more logging, analyze the logcat, reproduce... but all in vain. 

In an attempt to stabilize the app, we have upgraded to .net8.0-android and the number of crash was significantly reduced.
This problem happens on different kind of tablets, and we excluded the idea that it could come from firmware or hardware 
because they did not change and with .net framework (Xamarin) everything was running smoothly (1 crash rarely vs hundreds per day now).

Our dev and testing team (qa) are not able to reproduce the problem. Looking at the logs ([SIGSEGV_Samples_logcat-with-symbols.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16354417/SIGSEGV_Samples_logcat-with-symbols.txt)), we see that all of the SIGSEGV (SEGV_MAPERR) happens on the SGen worker thread but give different backtraces.
At the end of the log file, you’ll find a SIGABRT from SGen. We’ve kept it there for reference, in case it’s related to the SIGSEGV issues.

We used `dotnet-symbol` to retrieve a debug version of libmonosgen-2-0.so (with symbols). Then we run `ndk-stack` on our
logcat to symbolize the backtraces.

Application catches nothing. So we don't have any other traces to give from it. The logcat contains the most detailled 
ones we have.

FYI, we did split our crashes into 3 categories, we're not sure that they related to the SIGSEGV... 
but to give you all data, the other 2 are : 
- Fatal signal 6 (SIGABRT), code -1 (SI_QUEUE) in tid ***** (|ANR-WatchDog|), pid ***** (com.isaac.onthego)
- Fatal signal 6 (SIGABRT), code -1 (SI_QUEUE) in tid ***** (enableInternal), pid ***** (com.android.nfc)

What we tried : 

- Reproducing by running our acceptance tests on the tablet
-> Nothing happens unless we run the day long tests and it's very rare. It does not give more information than what we have in production.
- Upgrading .net version (from 8.0.100 to 8.0.303)
-> Nothing changed.

- **Revert to .Net Framework (Xamarin)**
-> We did it in order to identify if it's related to our changes or the framework. **And it worked !!!  
The number of crash were back to normal (before .net6 and .net8).** 

- *** ***EDIT*** *** We also tried to disable trimming by settings `<PublishTrimmed>false</PublishTrimmed>` in all of our .csproj.
-> Our APK was a little bit heavier (of course) and no changes in number of crashes..


What we are still probing :  
 
- Disabling concurrency on Mono Garbage collector and change the bridge-implementation to old  
-> We’ve seen numerous issues and discussions about the stability of SGen. We are hoping that this change can make a difference, as the backtraces seem to point to a problem that could be within it. If this works, it could allow us to stay with .net8 until a fix is found.

Thank you in advance for your help. We will remain vigilant if you need more details.

### Steps to Reproduce

Unfortunetaly we are unable to reproduce the problem in step by step as it appears randomly on production.

### Did you find any workaround?

Currently, reverting to the .Net Framework appears to be effective for us.

### Relevant log output

```shell
See attached files of the description
```

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body: @dcrespo-isaac thanks for the logs! They universally show that the issue is somewhere in the MonoVM's GC (SGEN), so I think the issue belongs in `dotnet/runtime`.  Would you happen to still have the logs that have `SIGABRT` in them? The reason I ask is that they would contain more information **before** the native stack trace is dumped.  The information will contain the actual assertion message logged by MonoVM - and this message is crucial to understanding what's going on.  If you could share these logs, or scour them for any log lines containing any assertions coming from MonoVM and paste them here, it would be very helpful. Thanks!

nodes.author: akoeplinger
nodes.body: @BrzVlad looks like a GC issue

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body: @dcrespo-isaac Scan the logs for messages containing strings similar to `* Assertion at` which are tagged either with an empty string, `DOTNET` or a fragment of your application's ID.  The message will also contain a file path which should have `mono` component in it.

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Thank you for the triage. 

I've found the logcat I had analyzed for the SIGSEGV errors. In the [logcat-Assertion.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16366700/logcat-Assertion.txt), you'll find two samples of SIGABRT preceded by :

```Assertion at /__w/1/s/src/mono/mono/metadata/object.c:4410, condition `is_ok (error)' not met, function:mono_unhandled_exception_internal, (null) assembly:System.Private.CoreLib.dll type:ArgumentNullException member:(null)```

Additional notes:

- The SIGABRT assertion error is always the same, but it sometimes occurs on the `ANR_WatchDog` thread and other times on what appears to be the main thread `com.isaac.onthego`.
- The two samples show errors just after the start of the application. It’s true that some errors occur then, but others occur at different moments – sadly at random times – throughout the lifetime of the application.
- The number of SIGSEGV crashes is substantially higher than that of SIGABRT.
-> We attempted to identify a pattern between SIGSEGV and SIGABRT, but found nothing significant. This means that they don’t precede or follow each other in any particular way.

I will continue to update the issue if I encounter any other assertion errors.

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body: @dcrespo-isaac I don't have any insight for the SIGSEGV, but for SIGABRT - does your app have a `AppDomain.CurrentDomain.UnhandledException` event handler installed?  the assertion on object.c:4410 looks like it's due to an unhandled null reference exception during the execution of the unhandled exception handler.

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Hi @lambdageek,

First and foremost, thank you for your response. It is greatly appreciated. We have identified the origin of the SIGABRT:

- There was indeed a null reference that was triggered due to a race condition at startup.
- We discovered a setter in ANR_WatchDog that allows us to handle an ANR in our own way, rather than allowing the tool to crash our application.

Regarding this open issue, we continue to experience problems with SIGSEGV, which is the primary subject of this issue and, regrettably, the cause of the majority of our crashes.

We are currently deploying our reverted version to Xamarin, as it has proven to be significantly more stable. We will remain vigilant for any responses, fixes, or requests for additional information regarding this issue.

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Hi Team, @mangod9 ,

We noticed a few weeks ago that the issue was moved to the “Future” milestones.

While “No due date” is quite clear, it leaves us with a significant span of uncertainty, especially since Xamarin is no longer supported. We would like to manage our expectations regarding this issue. Will it be fixed or at least investigated by your team of experts?

Currently, we have had to completely rollback all our projects to the old .NET Framework/Xamarin to reduce crashes due to SIGSEGV.

Please let us know if there are any troubleshooting techniques or tools we can use to provide you with more information, or ideally, find a fix ourselves.

We look forward to hearing more on this thread,
Best regards to your team.

nodes.author: mangod9
nodes.body: Hello @dcrespo-isaac, you mention that the issue is reduced in 8, but still occurs occasionally?

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Hi @mangod9,

It appears there may have been a misunderstanding regarding the issue.
The concern is about an **increase** in the number of SIGSEGV occurrences on .NET 8 (specifically on the SGen Worker), not a decrease.

Our workaround was to revert to Xamarin because it:

- Fixed the SIGSEGV errors on the SGen Worker, which is the primary focus of this thread.
- Generally reduced the number of crashes and SIGSEGVs (null dereference). These errors are challenging to troubleshoot, but we believe they are not an issue with .NET. Consequently, we did not open an issue for them. Still we'd appreciate any insights you could give us.

nodes.author: mangod9
nodes.body: Hi @vitek-karas, since this is on Android can you please provide guidance on diagnostic steps. Is there a way to collect some dumps when the failure occurs?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: This issue looks like duplicate of https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/100311. Did disabling concurrent GC lead to fixing of the crashes ? This issue seems somewhat impossible to investigate without a repro. However, I think we can give an attempt to investigate whether something is wrong with the GC by trying some debug flags like `MONO_GC_DEBUG=check-remset-consistency,mod-union-consistency-check,collect-before-allocs,verify-before-allocs`. Some of this options might be bitrotten so it would be ideal if we could have access to run the application ourseleves.

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Hi @BrzVlad,

I reviewed issue #100311, which pertains to SIGABRT. We no longer face issues with SIGABRT; this thread is actually about SIGSEGV. 
_EDIT_: SIGSEGV issues did not give us assertion errors (in logcat) while SIGABRT would usually do.

However, @pijnappel has created an issue that seems similar to ours: dotnet/maui#21479. 
Additionally, dotnet/runtime#109459 appears to be related as well.

We plan to beta test the version without concurrent GC in a few days and will keep everyone updated. Thank you for the MONO_GC_DEBUG options; I was unaware of some of them, and they could be helpful.

What exactly would you need to run everything on your end?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
When there are GC problems, the application can crash in a variety of ways, they are non-deterministic by nature. I am almost certain that the underlying issue is the same and based on comments on other issues it seems that the culprit is somewhere in the concurrent collector.

Note that I'm getting crashes with some of these debug options locally on some of our tests suites that are somewhat heavier on the GC. I will have to do a little bit of investigation to see whether they are false positives or not and see if these constraints from the debug options are respected in our own tests suites, before investigating anything on a mobile app.

Assuming we can't reproduce this issue, the second approach I would take is to understand more or less what the application was doing when it crashed and then attempt to do more or less the same thing locally, with some different gc params / debug options, in the hope of catching some inconsistencies in the GC. I think an apk with the application with some instructions on what to do in the app could be useful. @grendello I am assuming one could easily unzip an apk, patch `libmonosgen-2.0.so` and then zip it back to have the application run with custom runtime, right ?

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body: @BrzVlad Replacing a shared library in the apk requires that you re-align and re-sign the archive, or it won't install and run on the device/emulator.  Signing process records sha256 hashes of the shared libraries.  When you need to do that, ping us on Discord in the #android channel, we'll help you out :)

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: @dcrespo-isaac In addition to testing with concurrent gc disabled, I think it would be worthwhile to keep concurrent gc enabled but use the flags `MONO_GC_PARAMS=evacuation-threshold=0,no-precleaning` which disables some functionality that seems involved in the crash reports.

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
@BrzVlad, 

Thank you. We will develop a plan to test the different options and will get back to you with the data. At the very least, we will have two versions:

- Concurrent GC disabled, debug improved with `check-remset-consistency,mod-union-consistency-check,collect-before-allocs,verify-before-allocs`
- Concurrent GC enabled, debug improved with `check-remset-consistency,mod-union-consistency-check,collect-before-allocs,verify-before-allocs`, options `evacuation-threshold=0,no-precleaning`

Additionally, I am compiling information to create a brief documentation on how you can test our .apk on your end.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
Don't use the `mod-union-consistency-check`, there seems to be some issues with it. Also note that `collect-before-allocs,verify-before-allocs` are absurdly heavy, maybe use them just for a few runs manually to see if they happen to report anything, I don't think it would be worthwhile to stress test with it. I would say it is best to first run without any debug flags just to see whether the gc options might fix the crash and only afterwards attempt to run with gc flags on the crashing configurations.

So some explicit configurations could be
* concurrent gc disabled
* concurrent gc enabled with `evacuation-threshold=0,no-precleaning`
* concurrent gc enabled with `check-remset-consistency`
* concurrent gc enabled with `check-remset-consistency,collect-before-allocs=100`

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Hi, Quick update,

We're sorry for the delay, we should be able to test and give you more data by next week.

nodes.author: dcrespo-isaac
nodes.body:
Hi, @BrzVlad,

Sorry this took so long; we had a lot of work to do to release our new beta version.

Quick reminder: 

- Releasing a version is our only way to reproduce crashes.
- Automation tests and tests by developers don't trigger issues.

About the .apk:

- We considered sending you an apk, but you wouldn't be able to run it. Our application requires a specific setup to run (our manufactured Android tablet, pairing to our truck gateway for telemetry, etc.).

What we have found: 

- `Upgraded to 8.0.402`
 Does not solve the issue.
- `concurrent gc disabled`
It works great ! The number of crashes is equal to that of Xamarin versions. **This could be a great workaround to stay on .NET 8** instead of rolling back to Xamarin. We have not experienced any trouble with garbage collection times so far, but it will be a concern if we release the version outside the beta.
- `concurrent gc enabled with evacuation-threshold=0,no-precleaning`
It works better than no options. The number of crashes was reduced, but not as much as disabling concurrency or using the Xamarin version.

- `concurrent gc enabled with check-remset-consistency `
Untested
- `concurrent gc enabled with check-remset-consistency,collect-before-allocs=100`
Untested


Do you suggest we investigate the last two options, or should we stick with disabling concurrency for now?
Have you find anything on your side ?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
My current understanding is that concurrent GC was enabled by default with the new .NET versions (5+). Concurrent GC was supported in legacy Xamarin but you needed to explicitly add it in the csproj (or click the option in the project editor). This would mean that using this configuration for .NET8 is not really a change in behavior and you shouldn't encounter any problems with pause times.

The `check-remset-consistency` option had some issues which I addressed recently. The new dotnet version with the fix should be available in 1-2 months. I would recommend its usage only once the new version is available, but for the sole purpose of helping us investigate the issue with concurrent GC that nobody is able to reliably reproduce so far. This debug option can end up more aggressively killing the runtime if a problem is found in the GC, so I understand if you wouldn't want to deploy an app with this enabled. However, giving it a try for localized testing would be appreciated.

nodes.author: IainS1986
nodes.body:
@BrzVlad How are you building with the concurrent GC disabled?

Are you just doing it in the csproj configuration with


    <AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>false</AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>

Or is there other build params/steps?

nodes.author: feric-isc
nodes.body:
Hello all. 
@dcrespo-isaac is away for a while and I will be taking over on our side for a while. 

Are there any other news related to this issue? 

On our side, we deployed the .NET8 version with concurrent gc disabled and it did allow us to get back to "xamarin-like" levels of the SIGSEGV/SIGQUIT/SIGABRT levels. So the good news is we were able to jump on the .NET side of things.

The issue is, I still find that the level of these SIGSEGV/SIGQUIT/SIGABRT to be unreasonably high. 1 in 5 of our devices will get this exception every day (unfortunately we're not able to pinpoint when...very random).

Browsing through this site, I found a few other issues like https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/100311 or https://github.com/dotnet/android/issues/8253#issuecomment-2380714158. Could these be related and if so, do you have any other suggestion on how to reduce these exceptions?

I also saw this issue: https://github.com/dotnet/android/issues/9365. We do have some ANRs that seem to have increased in this new version... I will be following this thread as well as I see it is very active but I'm guessing they couldn't have the same root cause?

nodes.author: BrzVlad

nodes.author: feric-isc
nodes.body:
Hi @BrzVlad,

For SIGSEGV errors, here are a few traces from the crashed threads (this is the most current error found): 
 Crashed: Thread: SIGSEGV  0x0000000000000000
#00 pc 0x75cc5cccd0

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body: @BrzVlad I usually do it by hand using `llvm-addr2line` but yes, `ndk-stack` should work fine. You can get the symbols by extracting `libmonosgen-2.0.so` from the apk, then using the `dotnet-symbol` tool (`dotnet-symbol libmonosgen-2.0.so`). This will place the debug symbols next to the code .so and `ndk-stack` should be able to symbolicate the trace.

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body: @BrzVlad multiple symbols per frame might be caused by inlining, since debug information keeps data about inlined functions.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: Still, in this example `mono_metadata_decode_row_col_raw` cannot possibly call `mono_method_to_ir` not directly or ever. Also `mono_array_new_full_checked` ending up calling `mono_metadata_localscope_from_methoddef` seems implausible. Unless half the runtime code is inlined.. And these are the only symbols in the stacktrace for this thread for example ..

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body:
@BrzVlad it's possible the debug data is mismatched, somehow. However, the way to read the multiple entries is that the first one in a frame is the one called by the previous frame, so `mono_array_new_full_checked` calls `mono_metadata_decode_row_col_raw` which, eventually, calls `mono_method_to_ir` (via, possibly inlined, `mono_metadata_localscope_from_methoddef`). It really doesn't make much sense, just judging by the method names without looking at the source code though... :)

Another possibility is that Mono runtime was compiled without frame pointers and that the stack trace generator just gets lost.

nodes.body:
Hello @BrzVlad . Here are 2 additional symbolized stacktraces (with their non-symbolicated files they were generated from). 

[sigsegv1.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21221750/sigsegv1.txt)
[sigsegv1_symbolized.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21221751/sigsegv1_symbolized.txt)
[sigsegv2.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21221752/sigsegv2.txt)
[sigsegv2_symbolized.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21221753/sigsegv2_symbolized.txt)

Here is what I did to symbolicate. Let me know if something is not ok.

1. Downloaded stacktrace from Crashlytics Firebase (made sure to validate the crash was with our latest version that was built with .NET SDK 8.0.410
2. Unzipped libmonosgen-2.0.so
3. Ran command dotnet-symbol libmonosgen-2.0.so. Generated dotnet-symbol libmonosgen-2.0.dbg
4. Ran the following python script to generate the symbolicated traces

```python
import re
import subprocess

# === Configuration ===
STACKTRACE_FILE = "sigsegv2.txt"
OUTPUT_FILE = "sigsegv2_symbolized.txt"
DBG_FILE = r"libmonosgen-2.0.so.dbg"
LLVM_SYMBOLIZER = "llvm-symbolizer.exe" 

# === Regex to match libmonosgen lines ===
libmono_re = re.compile(r'#\d+\s+pc\s+(0x[0-9a-f]+)\s+libmonosgen-2\.0\.so', re.IGNORECASE)

def symbolize_address(addr: str) -> str:
    """Call llvm-symbolizer with one address and return the symbolized result."""
    try:
        result = subprocess.run(
            [LLVM_SYMBOLIZER, f"--obj={DBG_FILE}", addr],
            stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
            stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
            text=True,
            check=True
        )
        return result.stdout.strip()
    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e:
        return f"[symbolization failed: {e.stderr.strip()}]"

def main():
    with open(STACKTRACE_FILE, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f_in, open(OUTPUT_FILE, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f_out:
        for line in f_in:
            f_out.write(line)
            match = libmono_re.search(line)
            if match:
                addr = match.group(1)
                symbolized = symbolize_address(addr)
                for sym_line in symbolized.splitlines():
                    f_out.write(f"    ==> {sym_line}\n")
    print(f"✅ Symbolized output written to: {OUTPUT_FILE}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

nodes.author: feric-isc
nodes.body: Hi @BrzVlad. Are these traces better?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
The stacktraces are definitely correct this time, thanks for taking the time to symbolicate the reports. There are no symbols for `libc.so` and `libart.so` so I can't be 100% that there are no other issues somewhere else outside of the runtime. I've seen crashes before in the art GC or in other places. At least we know there no crashes in the .NET runtime.

Having said that, if we are to assume that the first reported thread is the one that is crashing (I think this should be the case but I don't have full trust in these reports), this points to a null pointer dereference in managed code crashing the application. This normally should be impossible, a NRE should be thrown, unless the signal handlers have been tampered with. We've recently uncovered such an issue, fixed by https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/118085. So if your application uses `Process.Start` or `System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping`, this means you are hitting the above mentioned issue.

nodes.author: feric-isc
nodes.body: Thanks for your feedback @BrzVlad . We checked and we don't seem to use Process.Start or System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping. Is that something you deduced from our stacktraces? If we don't use them, do you still think it could be related to the issue you mentioned? I seem to see that it has been backported in .NET9. So if we update to latest of .NET9 and we still have the issue, what then? We are planning to do so in the next month or so...

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
The version containing the mentioned fix will be 9.0.10. So it will take a while before you can try it out (I think around 1.5 months). To me it just feels like the only plausible explanation, but I wouldn't be overly confident about it. In order to validate this in the meantime, you could try to use the following environment flag: `MONO_DEBUG=explicit-null-checks` (this avoids usage of signals when throwing NRE). You should be able to tweak the environment by adding the value to a new file and then include this file in the build as an android environment file. For example:
```
<ItemGroup>
        <AndroidEnvironment Include="Platforms\Android\Environment.txt" />
</ItemGroup>
````

You might want to check at runtime with `Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable` to see that the env var is set correctly, there have been some issues in the past (only with debug builds I think).

title: # Fatal signal 11 (SIGSEGV), code 1 (SEGV_MAPERR), fault addr ************ in tid **** (SGen worker)

author: kklose23
body:
### Description

This is happening when using shell navigation to navigate to a bunch of pages.  Unfortunately I was unable to reproduce it on a simpler project to post.  So I'm uncertain exactly what's causing this.  However, it was working on MAUI version 8.0.40 and broke on subsequent versions.

I was able to reproduce on the Android emulator

Others have posted about this as well:
https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/23827
https://github.com/dotnet/maui/discussions/23634
https://github.com/dotnet/maui/discussions/23826

### Steps to Reproduce

See description

### Link to public reproduction project repository

_No response_

### Version with bug

8.0.60 SR6

### Is this a regression from previous behavior?

Yes, this used to work in .NET MAUI

### Last version that worked well

8.0.40 SR5

### Affected platforms

Android

### Affected platform versions

_No response_

### Did you find any workaround?

No

### Relevant log output

nodes.author: filipnavara
nodes.body:
I have a pretty good idea why is this happening.

This code path can introduce duplicates into the `color->other_colors` array:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/b658cd25af266afbde9f83f77d13519de9f533f0/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-tarjan-bridge.c#L795-L798

Then we get to the code that counts `xref_count`:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/b658cd25af266afbde9f83f77d13519de9f533f0/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-tarjan-bridge.c#L1101-L1114

It uses the `color_visible_to_client` helper method which in turn calls `bridgeless_color_is_heavy`:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/b658cd25af266afbde9f83f77d13519de9f533f0/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-tarjan-bridge.c#L131-L139

The `fanout` metric is computed from the count of `other_colors` which contain duplicates. Once the references are gathered with `gather_xrefs` they get deduplicated. This can change the number of fanout nodes just enough that it no longer satisfies the "heavy" property. We still increase the `xref_count` but in the second loop that iterates over the same data it will get skipped and result in a mismatch:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/b658cd25af266afbde9f83f77d13519de9f533f0/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-tarjan-bridge.c#L1126-L1130

Presumably it can be further simplified.

Not sure if this is relevant or not. Also, this is my first comment ever.

`
                                <dx:DXImage

`

CommunityToolkit.Maui 11.2.0
CommunityToolkit.Mvvm 8.4.0
Microsoft.Maui.Controls 9.0.50

I unfortunately can't share any specifics.

> Thats a great find! I am actually also using tintbehavior from CommunityToolkit in my project and I also experienced this issue. This should be flagged in the CommunityToolkit as well if thats truly the culprit.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: I have mixed opinions on backporting this. The bug itself is not a regression, it is moderate in risk and there should be an available workaround of using the fallback `new` bridge. Why would this by critical for backporting ?

nodes.author: filipnavara
nodes.body:
> Why would this by critical for backporting ?

The problem is that the `new` bridge is not the default, so more people are bound to run into this and have a bad experience. It's often quite difficult to trace back the issue to the root cause (in this case the logcat logs may not be captured in some error tracking platforms like Sentry; with the other fixed issue you'd just get non-sensical `ObjectDisposedException`s and no other clue). Given that this is affecting developers on supported runtime versions we should address it in servicing. The question is how to address it. We are basically left with couple of options:
- .NET 8 is going out of support on mobile soon, so we may recommend the workaround there and leave it as is.
- .NET 9 is going to be supported for another year, so something should be done there. The options are changing the default bridge or backporting the fixes (and possibly the tests). I'd argue that the safer choice is the later but I could be swayed either way. Uno has switches to `new` some time ago which slighly increases my confidence that there are no hidden bugs there.
 
I can open the backport PR if that saves some time.

nodes.author: DanielGlick
nodes.body:
Due to the issue that we cant set `MONO_GC_PARAMS=bridge-implementation=new` on our builds when FastDeployment is enabled, this only changed our release builds. Now when we are running in debug, we may still run into this crash. This is an annoyance and now before we open a new ticket for a crash in our system, we have to check if this is the crash listed here. 

Also, now our debug builds are using different GC things, which can lead to inconsistencies in different configurations. 

We dont want to just disable FastDeployment to get the new bridge because that significantly increases the deploy time (obviously).

That is why we would want to see this backported to .net 9.

global.json
```
{
  "sdk": {
    "version": "9.0.305",
    "workloadVersion": "9.0.305",
    "rollForward": "disable",
    "allowPrerelease": false
  }
}
```

However, it doesn't crash if I add the file Environment.txt (set to `MONO_GC_PARAMS=bridge-implementation=new`, per the workaround from https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/106410#issuecomment-2391391866).

nodes.author: filipnavara
nodes.body: @zzyzy It's the same one as reported few comments above. Definitely related to the original issue. Do you by any chance have a reproducible test case that triggers it?

title: [Android] App crashing with condition `xref_count == xref_index' not met

author: matouskozak
body:
I've noticed several crashes in `Perf_Regex_Common` microbenchmark group with common crash pattern. 

Build: https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_build/results?buildId=2545451

Affected microbenchmarks:
- `System.Text.RegularExpressions.Tests.Perf_Regex_Common.Backtracking(Options: IgnoreCase, Compiled)`

- `System.Text.RegularExpressions.Tests.Perf_Regex_Common.MatchesSet(Options: IgnoreCase, Compiled)`

- `System.Text.RegularExpressions.Tests.Perf_Regex_Common.Email_IsNotMatch(Options: IgnoreCase, Compiled)`
- `System.Text.RegularExpressions.Tests.Perf_Regex_Common.CtorInvoke(Options: IgnoreCase, Compiled)`
- `System.Text.RegularExpressions.Tests.Perf_Regex_Common.Uri_IsNotMatch(Options: IgnoreCase, Compiled)`

nodes.author: matouskozak
nodes.body:
Looking at the managed stack trace, this issue could be possibly related to GC. What do you think @BrzVlad ?

I also see `../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/wait4.c: No such file or directory.` in the crash, wonder if something related to threading could be playing part here.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: This is definitely GC crash, related to a live object being collected. I'll try to reproduce in the future.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body: @matouskozak is this something new? Or it's possible we've had this previously and didn't see it?

nodes.author: matouskozak
nodes.body:
> @matouskozak is this something new? Or it's possible we've had this previously and didn't see it?

Not sure, we had a long standing AOT failures https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/106914 that were taking a large portion of failures. These got fixed recently so it's possible that we just didn't notice the failures before.

title: [WASI][Mono] allocating pages with alignment wastes memory

author: vsfeedback
body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Random-SIGSEGVs-after-porting-from-Xamar/10602677)._

---
[severity:I'm unable to use this version]
The last major release of our software followed our porting of the software from Xamarin.Android to net8.0-android. Everything appeared to go well in our own tests, but we are getting a lot of reports of crashes out in the wild. We have been unable to reproduce any problem in our office, but with tens of thousands of customers using the software every day, this crashing is a major problem for us.

We've been receiving no managed crash reports via our own telemetry, so we suspected this was a runtime issue. Finally a tech-savvy customer has sent us some debug output, which I'll paste below. We also have some sample stack traces from the Play Store telemetry which I will also paste below.

What I urgently need is for someone knowledgeable on runtime issues to advise if there's a component clearly at fault that we can temporarily turn off or avoid, so we can get back to having a stable app. I could roll back to Xamarin.Android but that is not sustainable long term.

I can provide further log output sent by a customer, but cannot post it publicly due to privacy concerns. Sending it securely to Microsoft will be fine.

<p>I have tons of those. All look a bit different. I have no idea where to start searching for a solution. I’m really thankful for any advice.</p>

#### Jonathan Pryor [MSFT] on 4/11/2024, 11:47 AM: 

<p>We would ideally like a repro, or at minimum <em>all</em> the relevant <code>adb logcat</code> output, particularly output <em>before</em> the <code>Fatal signal 11 (SIGSEGV), code 1 (SEGV_MAPERR)</code> message.  “Relevant output” being output from the originating PID; for example, given this message:</p>
<pre><code><span class="hljs-selector-tag">Fatal</span> <span class="hljs-selector-tag">signal</span> 11 (<span class="hljs-selector-tag">SIGSEGV</span>), <span class="hljs-selector-tag">code</span> 1 (<span class="hljs-selector-tag">SEGV_MAPERR</span>), <span class="hljs-selector-tag">fault</span> <span class="hljs-selector-tag">addr</span> 0<span class="hljs-selector-tag">x37</span> <span class="hljs-selector-tag">in</span> <span class="hljs-selector-tag">tid</span> 6482 (<span class="hljs-selector-tag">ctro</span><span class="hljs-selector-class">.mobile</span><span class="hljs-selector-class">.xrf</span>), <span class="hljs-selector-tag">pid</span> 6482 (<span class="hljs-selector-tag">ctro</span><span class="hljs-selector-class">.mobile</span><span class="hljs-selector-class">.xrf</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>we’d want all messages from PID 6482.</p>
<p>For example, consider <a target='_blank' href="https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/96872">https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/96872</a>, which was an assertion failure leading to a crash.  This left a message in <code>adb logcat</code>, but it was <em>before</em> the <code>Fatal signal …</code> message:</p>
<pre><code>* Assertion at /__w/<span class="hljs-number">1</span>/s/src/mono/mono/metadata/object.c:<span class="hljs-number">657</span>, condition `lock->done' <span class="hljs-keyword">not</span> met
</code></pre>
<p><em>Just</em> the tombstone, or <em>just</em> <code>adb logcat</code> output starting with <code>Fatal signal</code>, will not contain such assertion messages.</p>
<p>See also <a target='_blank' href="https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/98933">https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/98933</a>, which appears to be the “original” report of the “Random SIGSEGVs after porting” issue.</p>

#### Tim Dawson on 4/12/2024, 02:41 AM: 

<p>Jonathan, did I not upload an entire “tombstone” report sent to us by a customer a few posts up? That contains comprehensive logcat output.</p>

#### Timo Pijnappel on 8/27/2024, 06:08 AM: 

<p>Is there any progress on this? These crashes are still happening, for multiple people as seen in multiple issues on GitHub (Maui, dotnet/runtime). I will gladly assist with debugging. I cannot reproduce the crash, but I can trigger it once or twice a day on my Android device in release mode.</p>
<p>Here is a full logcat of the issue.<br>
<a target='_blank' href="https://aka.ms/dc/file?name=Bb0007edc00d44a549fbb94eef18769f5638603609175960495_LOG-27.08.2024.log&tid=b0007edc00d44a549fbb94eef18769f5638603609175960495">LOG-27.08.2024.log</a></p>

nodes.author: pijnappel
nodes.body:
As mentioned here: [https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/21479](https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/21479)

We found a workaround. The chrashes vanish if we deactivate concurrent garbage collection in the project settings.

`<AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>False</AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent>`

I am not sure about the side effects and impacts on performance. When running calculation processes, we see random pauses of the execution for 300ms or more. I assume this happens when the GC is triggered. I haven't found a way to pause the GC for the duration of our calculations.

nodes.author: fgiacomelli
nodes.body:
I report the same problem, in a .NET based application, since we updated the .NET framework from version 7.0 to 8.0 we started to encounter random crashes, which are not intercepted by the UnhandledException handler.

We have currently tried the workaround suggested above disabling the AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent, it seems to have produced some slight improvement but we continue to experience crashes in a non-deterministic way, and the issue is particularly worrying since we have no possibility to log the information.

This is an excerpt from one of the cases we managed to reproduce and for which we extracted the dump:

`2025-04-11 16:01:35.506  2923-2923  FantasyApp.Name                FantasyApp.Name                             E  * Assertion at /__w/1/s/src/mono/mono/metadata/sgen-tarjan-bridge.c:1174, condition ``xref_count == xref_index' not met, function:processing_build_callback_data, xref_count is 757 but we added 754 xrefs
2025-04-11 16:01:35.515  2923-2923  libc                    FantasyApp.Name                             A  Fatal signal 6 (SIGABRT), code -1 (SI_QUEUE) in tid 2923 (FantasyApp.Name), pid 2923 (FantasyApp.Name)
2025-04-11 16:01:35.708  3859-3859  DEBUG                   pid-3859                             A  pid: 2923, tid: 2923, name: FantasyApp.Name  >>> FantasyApp.Name <<<
2025-04-11 16:01:36.150  3859-3859  DEBUG                   crash_dump64                         A        #01 pc 000000000002680c  /data/app/~~p7N4yQK2yfID41usXJfusQ==/FantasyApp.Name-72jNHRQS_neyYflP2us0pw==/lib/arm64/libmonodroid.so (xamarin::android::Helpers::abort_application()+8) (BuildId: b9f616d826c0b03c1b047c5621df9afd2155ec5c)

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
The last comment references an issue which was resolved with https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/116069. That should be in 9.0.7. So hopefully at least some of the other problems reported here will get fixed by that as well - it's very hard to tell from the information available.

/cc @BrzVlad

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
The issues from the comments should be fixed in 9.0.7 and 9.0.8. There is not much we can do for the original issue without a repro and there is a valid workaround for it.

@pijnappel  Before closing this, would it be possible to test locally with the following debug environment variable: `MONO_GC_DEBUG=check-remset-consistency` (with concurrent GC). You can set it on device via adb shell for example: `adb shell setprop debug.mono.env "MONO_GC_DEBUG=check-remset-consistency"`. This will do some additional checks that could help get the app to crash more deterministically or with more info.

nodes.author: juwens
nodes.body:
It's 1.5 years since this issue was [initially reported](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/98933). 3 months after .Net 8 release.

1.5 years without fixing it in the current officially supported .Net release.

.Net 8 is supported until Nov 2026. it's ridiculous that these kind of severe bugs do not get fixed for .Net 8.
And that customers are forced to jump to the latest buggy major version, which doesn't receive updates in a few weeks.
Only to be in the same predicament again.

nodes.author: steveisok
nodes.body:
> .Net 8 is supported until Nov 2026. it's ridiculous that these kind of severe bugs do not get fixed for .Net 8. And that customers are forced to jump to the latest buggy major version, which doesn't receive updates in a few weeks. Only to be in the same predicament again.

.NET 8 fell out of support for mobile runtimes back in May 2025. Please see https://dotnet.microsoft.com/en-us/platform/support/policy/maui for more info.

This issue as reported has a suggested workaround and fixes we think addressed some of the comments. If you are continuing to experience issues, please (ideally) provide a repro or as much details as you can about your use case. Many times your problem may be different than the ones reported.

nodes.author: juwens
nodes.body: @steveisok thx for the clarification.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: Unfortunately, in this scenario, it appears that `check-remset-consistency` reports a false positive, which is awkward to fix. The reason is that, in a valuetype array where an element spans over multiple cards, it is enough to mark a single card for this element. This marked card will guarantee that the entire valuetype will be scanned. The remset consistency check doesn't take this into account so it can report false complaints.

nodes.author: srxqds
nodes.body:
> Unfortunately, in this scenario, it appears that `check-remset-consistency` reports a false positive, which is awkward to fix. The reason is that, in a valuetype array where an element spans over multiple cards, it is enough to mark a single card for this element. This marked card will guarantee that the entire valuetype will be scanned. The remset consistency check doesn't take this into account so it can report false complaints.

so, hope you can fix this problem, This issue has a great impact on us!

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: There is another gc debug option: `MONO_GC_DEBUG=binary-protocol=output-file`. If you have this enabled in addition to `check-remset-consistency`, it will not crash but rather just report the found issues. You could then check the console output to see if there are any other missing remsets aside from these false positives. (The false positives should be easy to identify because they happen in a array of valuetypes where the missing card is for an address at a card boundary. In your example, the missing card is for an address at `0x24F68424130` + 1744 which is `0x24F68424800`, right at a card boundary; a card is for a region of `0x200` bytes)

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
Is this crash happening also on android ? Some of the other reports could also be due to gc issues. I think it is best to follow up on this check remset consistency report.

Could you attempt to obtain the same remset consistency failure with the following diff:

```
diff --git a/src/mono/mono/sgen/sgen-debug.c b/src/mono/mono/sgen/sgen-debug.c
index ea2caeba2b6..c9f1f27a7d8 100644
--- a/src/mono/mono/sgen/sgen-debug.c
+++ b/src/mono/mono/sgen/sgen-debug.c
@@ -163,8 +163,11 @@ static gboolean missing_remsets;
                                gboolean is_pinned = object_is_pinned (*(ptr)); \
                                SGEN_LOG (0, "Oldspace->newspace reference %p at offset %ld in object %p (%s.%s) not found in remsets%s.", *(ptr), (long)((char*)(ptr) - (char*)(obj)), (obj), sgen_client_vtable_get_namespace (__vt), sgen_client_vtable_get_name (__vt), is_pinned ? ", but object is pinned" : ""); \
                                sgen_binary_protocol_missing_remset ((obj), __vt, (int) ((char*)(ptr) - (char*)(obj)), *(ptr), (gpointer)LOAD_VTABLE(*(ptr)), is_pinned); \
-                               if (!is_pinned)                         \
+                               if (!is_pinned) {                       \
+                                       mono_object_describe_fields (obj); \
+                                       mono_object_describe ((MonoObject*)*ptr); \
                                        missing_remsets = TRUE;         \
+                               }                                       \
                        }                                               \
                }                                                       \
        } while (0)
```

It might help explain why is there a missing wbarrier when storing into an `StateMachineBox`

i'm not sure, i don't try with another MONO_GC_PARAMS.
I can't find any way to reproduce it, i get this crash stacktrace from production app (Sentry crashlitics).

MONO_GC_DEBUG=check-remset-consistency will make the sentry stack trace more readable?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: Yes, it might provide some additional information in the crash trace. More importantly it might make it easier to reproduce the bug for follow up investigation (so keep that in mind if deploying directly in production). Separately, I would also definitely recommend not using any `MONO_GC_PARAMS` options to see if they influence the crash in any way.

Android, I was *not* able test on other platforms

net9.0-android35.0

nodes.author: SpaceTimee
nodes.body:
Btw I found a way to make the problem worse, which is to add GC.Collect(1) when Page Disappearing. If I don't add it or add GC.Collect(0), it takes exactly 5 times to open and close the About page before it crashes. But if I add GC.Collect(1), it only takes 2 times.
